resources.string: Allows an application to access AdServices Topics API.
Allows an application to access AdServices Attribution APIs.
Allows an application to access AdServices Custom Audience API.
Allows an application to access AdId API.
Allows an application to access AdServices Consent API.
Allows an application to access Ad ID API.
Access to App Set ID API
Allows an application to access App Set ID API.
Allows an application to access Consent Service API.
Access to AdService’s enablement state modification API
Allows an application to access AdService’s enablement state modification API.
Access to AdService’s enablement state API
Allows an application to access AdService’s enablement state API.
Allows an application to access AdServicesManager’s APIs.
Android is exploring more private ways for apps to show you ads
The new privacy features in the Privacy Sandbox let apps show you relevant ads, but restrict what those apps can learn about your activities on websites and apps from other developers.
Turning on the beta allows apps to test these new, more private ways to show you ads. You can turn off the beta any time in your privacy settings.
You’re part of Android’s ads privacy beta. The Privacy Sandbox is turned on for your device.\n\nYou can learn more or turn off the beta any time in your privacy settings.
Thanks for your response. The Privacy Sandbox is turned off for your device.\n\nIf you change your mind or want to learn more, go to your privacy settings.
The Privacy Sandbox is on for your device, and apps can test these new, more private ways to show you ads. You can turn off the beta any time in your privacy settings.

Android’s Privacy Sandbox provides new features that apps can use to show you ads you might like. These technologies don’t use device identifiers.\n\nAndroid and your apps can estimate the kinds of ads you might be interested in, and save the interests temporarily on your device. This allows apps to show you ads you might like, without tracking your activity across websites and apps from other developers.

Android periodically estimates your top interests based on the apps you use, for example, "Sports" or "Travel."

Later, an app can ask Android to use those interests to show you more relevant ads.

You can see the list of current interests in your privacy settings, and block any you don’t like.

Apps can estimate your interests and temporarily save these with Android. For example, an app you use to buy running shoes might estimate your interest as "running marathons."

Later, based on this interest, a different app can show you an ad related to marathons.

In your privacy settings, you can manage the list of apps that have saved interests.
Ad topics and new controls give you more choice over the ads you see
New ads privacy features now available

Android notes topics of interest based on apps you’ve used recently. Also, apps you use can determine what you like. Later, apps can ask for this information to show you personalized ads. You can choose which topics and apps are used to show you ads.
To measure the performance of an ad, limited types of data are shared between apps.
Apps can ask Android for information to help personalize the ads you see.
• Android notes topics of interest based on the apps you’ve used recently.

• Apps you use can also determine what you like based on how you use them. For example, if you use an app that sells long-distance running shoes, the app might decide that you’re interested in running marathons.
Later, an app you use can ask for this information — either your ad topics or ads suggested by apps you’ve used.
Android auto-deletes topics and app-suggested data regularly. You can also block specific topics and apps you don’t want to make suggestions.
Measuring how well an ad performs
Apps you use can ask Android for information to help them measure the performance of their ads. Android lets apps collect limited types of data, such as the time of day an ad was shown to you.
Ad topics give you more choice over the ads you see
Android is launching new privacy features that give you more choice over the ads you see.

Ad topics help apps show you relevant ads while protecting your identity and information about your app usage. Android can note topics of interest based on the apps you’ve used recently. Later, an app you use can ask Android for relevant topics to personalize the ads you see.
You can see ad topics in your device settings and block the ones you don’t want shared with apps. Android also auto-deletes ad topics regularly.
You can change your mind any time in privacy settings.
Learn more about how Android protects your data in our Privacy Policy.
Your ad topics are based on the apps you’ve used recently on this device and how frequently you use them.

Android notes topics of interest as you use your apps. Topic labels are predefined and include things like Arts & Entertainment, Shopping, and Sports. Later, an app you use can ask Android for a few of your topics (but not data about your app usage or identity) to personalize the ads you see.
• How you can manage your data

Android auto-deletes topics regularly. As you continue using apps, a topic might reappear on the list. You can also block topics you don’t want Android to share with apps, and turn ad topics off at any time in privacy settings.
You can make changes in privacy settings.
Other ads privacy features now available
Android also offers new ways to limit what apps can learn about you when they show you personalized ads.

• App-suggested ads help protect your identity and information about your app usage while enabling apps to show you relevant ads. Based on your activity, an app you use can suggest related ads on other apps. You can see a list of apps and block them from making suggestions, in privacy settings.
• With ad measurement, limited types of data are shared between apps to measure the performance of their ads, such as the time of day an ad was shown to you.
More about app-suggested ads and ad measurement
Your activity in an app you use on this device.

Apps can store information with Android about things you like. For example, if you use an app about marathon training, the app might decide that you’re interested in running shoes. Later, if you use a different app, that app can show you an ad for running shoes suggested by the first app.
• How you can manage your data
Android auto-deletes app-suggested data regularly. An app you use again might reappear on the list.
You can also block an app from suggesting ads for you, reset all ad-suggestion data, or turn app-suggested ads off at any time in privacy settings.
Apps you use can ask Android for information that helps them measure the performance of their ads. Android protects your privacy by limiting the information apps can share with one another.
New ads privacy features now available
Get more choice over the ads you see while protecting your identity
New ads privacy features now available
Android is launching new ways to limit what apps can learn about you when they show you personalized ads.

• With app-suggested ads, new privacy features help protect your identity and information about your app usage while enabling apps to show you relevant ads. Based on your activity, an app you use can suggest related ads on other apps. You can see a list of apps and block them from making suggestions in privacy settings.
• With ad measurement, limited types of data are shared between apps to understand the performance of their ads, such as the time of day an ad was shown to you.
Your activity in an app on this device can be used to suggest ads.
Turn on another ads privacy feature
Android also offers a new privacy feature that gives you more choice over the ads you see.

Ad topics help apps show you relevant ads while protecting your identity and information about your app usage. Android can note topics of interest based on apps you’ve used recently. Later, an app you use can ask Android for relevant topics to show you more relevant ads.
You can see ad topics in your privacy settings and block the ones you don’t want shared with apps. Android also auto-deletes ad topics regularly.
New ads privacy features now available
Now, there’s more choice over the ads you see while protecting your identity
New ads privacy features now available
Android now offers new privacy features that give you more choice over the ads you see.
Participate in Android’s ads privacy beta

Apps can use the Privacy Sandbox to measure the effectiveness of their ads. To do this, advertisers can temporarily save data with Android about your interactions between their ads and apps. The amount of data they can save is restricted and will be deleted regularly.\n\nYou can delete this data at any time by turning off the Privacy Sandbox.

Android periodically estimates your top interests based on the apps you use. Apps can ask Android to use those interests to show you more relevant ads.\n\nIf you block an interest, it won’t be added to the list again unless you unblock it. You might still see some related ads.
No interests to show right now.
No topics to show right now.\nLearn more about ad topics

Android’s ads privacy beta provides new features that apps can use to show you ads you might like. These technologies don’t use device identifiers.\n\nAndroid can estimate the kinds of ads you might be interested in, and save these interests temporarily on your device. This allows apps to show you relevant ads, without tracking your activity across websites and apps from other developers.

Apps can estimate your interests and temporarily save these with Android. Later, a different app can show you an ad based on these interests.\n\nIf you block an app, it won’t estimate any more interests. It won’t be added to this list of apps again unless you unblock it. Interests already estimated by the app will be deleted, but you might still see some related ads.
No apps are generating interests for you right now
No apps to show right now. \nLearn more about app-suggested ads

Android’s ads privacy beta provides new features that apps can use to show you ads you might like. These technologies don’t use device identifiers.\n\nApps can estimate the kinds of ads you might be interested in, and save these interests temporarily on your device. This allows apps to show you relevant ads, without tracking your activity across websites and apps from other developers.
Apps and advertisers can request information from Android that helps them measure the performance of their ads.\n\nAd measurement data is deleted regularly from your device.

Android protects your privacy by limiting the information apps can share with one another. Reports are sent with a delay to protect your identity.

Your browser may have a similar setting. If ad measurement is on for both Android and your browser, a company may be able to measure the effectiveness of an ad between apps you use and sites you visit. Your browsing history is kept private on your device.

Learn more about how Android protects your data in our Privacy Policy.
If you change your mind or want to learn more about Android’s ads privacy beta, go to your privacy settings
This topic will be blocked and won’t be added to your list again, unless you add it back. You may still see some related ads.
Android may add this topic to your list again, but it might not appear immediately
Your list will be cleared and new topics will be added going forward. You may still see some ads related to topics you’ve reset.
This app won’t suggest ads and won’t be added to your list again, unless you unblock it. You might still see some related ads.
This app can suggest ads for you again, but it might not appear on your list immediately. It might take a while for you to see related ads.
Ad-suggestion data from the apps on your list will be deleted and the apps will suggest new ads going forward. You may still see some related ads.
Android will start noting topics of interest, but it may take a while for your first topics to appear.
This list of topics will be deleted. Android won’t note topics of interest anymore, but you may still see relevant ads.
Apps may start suggesting ads. You’ll see a list of apps once they start suggesting ads.
All ad suggestion data will be deleted. Apps won’t be able to suggest ads anymore, but you may still see relevant ads.
Android can share only very limited information with apps to help apps measure the performance of their ads.
All pending ad measurement reports will be deleted and no new reports will be generated or shared.
[Copy for measurement] PlaceHolder of for measurement clear message dialog
Android notes topics of interest based on the apps you’ve used recently and how frequently you use them.
Apps you use can also determine what you like based on how you use them.
Apps you use can ask Android for information to help them measure the performance of their ads. Android lets apps collect limited types of data.
Learn more about ad privacy on Android

Topics of interest are based on the apps you’ve used recently, and are used by apps to show you personalized ads.\n\nYou can block topics you don’t want shared with apps. Android also auto-deletes topics regularly.

Android notes topics of interest based on the apps you’ve used in the last few weeks.

Later, an app you use can ask Android for your topics to personalize the ads you see. Android shares up to 3 topics while protecting your identity and information about your app usage.

Android auto-deletes topics regularly. As you continue using apps, a topic might reappear on the list. Or you can block topics you don’t want Android to share with apps.

In your apps, an ad you see may be personalized, depending on this setting, the app-suggested ads setting, your advertising ID settings, and whether the app you’re using personalizes ads.
Apps you use can determine what you like and then suggest ads on other apps.\n\nYou can block apps from making suggestions. Android also auto-deletes app-suggested data regularly.

It’s common for apps you use to remember things you’re interested in to personalize your experience. Apps can also store information with Android about your topics.

For example, if you use an app about marathon training, the app might decide that you’re interested in running shoes. Later, if you use a different app, that app can show you an ad for running shoes suggested by the first app.

Android auto-deletes app-suggested data regularly. An app you use again might reappear on the list. Or you can block an app from suggesting ads for you.

In your apps, an ad you see may be personalized, depending on this setting, the ad topics setting, your advertising ID settings, and whether the app you’re using personalizes ads.
Only very limited info is shared between apps to help measure ad performance

We’re launching a new ad privacy feature called ad measurement. Android shares only very limited information between apps, such as when an ad was shown to you, to help apps measure the performance of ads.
You can make changes in ad privacy settings.
Apps you use can ask Android for information to help them measure the performance of their ads. Android lets apps collect only limited types of data.
Colorful illustration of symbols representing topics of interest like music, news, and sports
Colorful illustration of a lock inside a circle

Small black and white illustration of simple shapes like a heart, triangle, and square
